thread.title: World Press Photo Contest winners
thread.title_full: World Press Photo Contest winners - Business Insider

author: Talia Lakritz
title: World Press Photo Contest winners
text:
A sea turtle in the Canary Islands swims despite its entanglements. Francis Pérez
The INSIDER Summary:
• The World Press Photo Contest highlights the best images from photojournalists around the world.
• They range from capturing current events to wildlife to humanitarian crises.
• The Photo of the Year depicts the assassination of the Russian Ambassador to Turkey.
Out of 80,408 pictures submitted by 5,034 photographers from 125 different countries, the World Press Photo Contest chooses only 129. These are the most breathtaking images of newsworthy events, serene landscapes, and tender moments , which are published and displayed worldwide in a traveling exhibit.
Some of the photos were splashed across front pages and social media , while others hold a more subtle power in their anonymity.
Here are 25 of the award-winning snapshots that made the cut.
View As: One Page Slides Mevlüt Mert Altıntaş shouts after shooting Andrey Karlov, the Russian ambassador to Turkey, at an art gallery in Ankara, Turkey. This was crowned the Photo of the Year. Burhan Ozbilici/The Associated Press Usain Bolt of Jamaica smiles as he looks back at his competition and wins the 100-meter semi-final sprint at the 2016 Olympics in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. Kai Oliver Pfaffenbach/Thomson Reuters Lone activist Ieshia Evans offers her hands for arrest as riot police charge towards her during a protest against police brutality in Baton Rouge, Louisiana. Jonathan Bachman/Thomson Reuters An African elephant under the starry sky. Bence Máté Fidel Castro's funeral procession in Santa Clara, Cuba. Tomas Munita/The New York Times Hunters in a small settlement near Nizhnyaya Tunguska River in Russia's extreme north. Elena Anosova Edilane and three of her seven children (at the time the photo was taken) rest on a mattress on the floor. “Copacabana Palace” in Brazil houses more than 300 homeless families. Peter Bauza Seven-year-old giant panda Min Min had a baby girl at Bifengxia Giant Panda Breeding and Research Center in Sichuan Province, China. Ami Vitale/National Geographic Magazine Muddy York Rugby Football Club player John-Paul Markides (left) kisses his partner and teammate Kasimir Kosakowski during the pride parade in Toronto, Ontario. Giovanni Capriotti A carpet of monarch butterflies covers the forest floor of El Rosario Butterfly Sanctuary, in Michoacán, Mexico. Jaime Rojo A man is treated with milk of magnesia after being pepper sprayed by police while protesting the Dakota Access Pipeline. Amber Bracken Adriana Cordeiro Soares, 30, bathes her son João Miguel, 3 months old, who was born with microcephaly caused by the Zika virus in Brazil. Lalo de Almeida/Folha de Sao Paulo Jockey Nina Carberry flies off her horse, Sir Des Champs, as they fall at The Chair fence during the Grand National steeplechase in Liverpool, England. Tom Jenkins/The Guardian Najiba holds her two-year-old nephew Shabir who was injured from a bomb blast in Kabul. Paula Bronstein/Time Lightbox/Pulitzer Center For Crisis Reporting Four students of a gymnastics school in Xuzhou, China, do toe-pressure training for 30 minutes in the afternoon. Tiejun Wang A family flees the fighting in Mosul, Iraq’s second-largest city, as oil fields burned in Qayyara, Iraq. Sergey Ponomarev/The New York Times A sea turtle entangled in a fishing net swims off the coast of Tenerife, Canary Islands, Spain. Francis Pérez Cheerleaders Melissa Bernadt and Jennifer Burnedt prepare for the evening’s homecoming game in Table Rock, Nebraska, a small rural community where nothing really changes. Markus Jokela/Helsingin Sanomat Hellen, 41, lives with a mental health problem. In African countries, treatment often comes in the form of prayer from a pastor or traditional healer. Robin Hammond/NOOR Images for Witness Change A wild leopard strolls through Sanjay Gandhi National Park, a protected area in the northern part of Mumbai, India. Nayan Khanolkar Lindsay Hilton from Nova Scotia, Canada, was born without arms and legs. She can lift 100 pounds with the help of chains from a local hardware store, straps, and Velcro. Darren Calabrese Gaël Monfils of France dives for a forehand in his fourth round match against Andrey Kuznetsov of Russia during the 2016 Australian Open. Cameron Spencer/Getty Images A chess player expresses his emotions during a game at a youth chess tournament in the Czech Republic. Michael Hanke Women play pool in an Iranian gym that is forbidden for women. Hossein Fatemi/Panos Pictures Inhabitants of a secluded and silent community they call the "Isle of Salvation," which is hidden near a busy road that leads from Moscow to Yaroslavl, Russia. Francesco Comello Read the original article on INSIDER . Follow INSIDER on Facebook . Copyright 2017. Follow INSIDER on Twitter .
